Tris what made the necessity of the Kludge PCB. The chip that did a level t=
ranslation of the 5V oscillator and flip flop to a 10v P-P double clock for=
 the Data chip was actually too slow and the rest of the clock system was a=
ctually out of sync at times.I've been actively looking to replace all of t=
he clock circuitry with something newer and more stable, but as of yout, I =
can't figure out a way to get the 7vP-P signal that is needed for the 10N t=
ranslators that are available.Ken


      From: "Adam Trionfo ballyalley@ho=
tmail.com [ballyalley]" <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com>
 To: "ballyalley@yahoo=
groups.com" <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com> 
 Sent: Tuesday, January 24, 2017 =
2:12 PM
 Subject: [ballyalley] Bally's 1979 Data Chip Clock Driver Fix
   
=
=C2=A0   This week, for the next episode of the Astrocast podcast, Paul and=
 I will be discussing several letters that were sent to theArcadian.=C2=A0 =
One letter, sent August 20, 1979, is from Jeff Frederiksen, the chief engin=
eer behind the design of the Bally Professional Arcade hardware. It seems t=
hat this letter was accompanied by some hardware. The letter simply states:=


"The enclosed assemblies replace the 75361 clock driver, located in the o=
scillator shield. The failure of the 75361 is that the 6V high time after w=
arm-up drops below 55ns causing the data chip to appear defective. If you d=
o not have this sinking clock syndrome, replacement is not necessary. I hop=
e you find the enclosed hardware description useful."

You can view the ori=
ginal letter here:

http://www.ballyalley.com/newsletters/arcadian/letters/=
letters.html#JeffFrederiksenLetterAugust201979
Unfortunately, this is all t=
he information this was included in the fabrics collection. Does anybody kn=
ow what Jeff is referring to here? Was this fix to the clock driver include=
d on later releases of the Astrocade motherboard?

Adam

    <div>


</div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yiv9557366030divtagdefaultwrapper"=
 style=3D"font-size:12pt;color:#000000;font-family:Calibri, Arial, Helvetic=
a, sans-serif;">
This week, for the next episode of the Astrocast podcast, =
Paul and I will be discussing several letters that were sent to the
<i id=
=3D"yui_3_16_0_ym19_1_1485286266230_4028">Arcadian</i>.  One letter, s=
ent August 20, 1979, is from Jeff Frederiksen, the chief engineer behind th=
e design of the Bally Professional Arcade hardware. It seems that this lett=
er was accompanied by some hardware. The letter simply states:<br clear=3D"=
none">
<br clear=3D"none">
"The enclosed assemblies replace the 75361 clock=
 driver, located in the oscillator shield. The failure of the 75361 is that=
 the 6V high time after warm-up drops below 55ns causing the data chip to a=
ppear defective. If you do not have this sinking clock syndrome,
 replaceme=
nt is not necessary. I hope you find the enclosed hardware description usef=
ul."<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
You can view the original lette=
r here:<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
<div><a rel=3D"nofollow" sha=
pe=3D"rect" tabindex=3D"-1" class=3D"yiv9557366030OWAAutoLink" id=3D"yiv955=
7366030LPlnk934532" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.ballyalley.com/new=
sletters/arcadian/letters/letters.html#JeffFrederiksenLetterAugust201979">h=
ttp://www.ballyalley.com/newsletters/arcadian/letters/letters.html#JeffFred=
eriksenLetterAugust201979</a></div>
<div><br clear=3D"none">
</div>
Unfortu=
nately, this is all the information this was included in the fabrics collec=
tion. Does anybody know what Jeff is referring to here? Was this fix to the=
 clock driver included on later releases of the Astrocade motherboard?<br c=
lear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
Adam<br clear=3D"none">
</div>




    <=
/div>
